Award.AwardTitle: MARGINS/GeoPRISMS Post-Doctoral Fellowship Research: Evolution of Sediment Physical Properties in the Nankai Subduction Zone and Implications for the Updip Limit of Seismogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Funds are provided for a post-doctoral study of deformation and slip behaviors in subduction systems by an experimental approach combined with seismic data and microstructure observations. The PIs will conduct friction experiments on smectite and illite at elevated temperature and measure the acoustic wave velocities on sediment core samples at different stress states. Results of the friction experiments will be used to further test the hypothesis of smectite-illite transition for updip limits of seismicity. The measurements of acoustic wave velocities at different stress states will allow the PIs to estimate the in-situ stress states and pore pressure in subduction systems by incorporating with seismic data. Samples and data from the IODP NanTroSEIZE transect area will be used to investigate the in situ stress and pore pressure conditions.

Broader Impacts
The award will support a young female researcher as a MARGINS/GeoPRISMS postdoctoral fellow. The proposed research aims to understand the evolution of slip behavior at the upper limit of the seismogenic zone and the deformation mechanisms in subduction zone fault systems and accretionary prisms. The focal points of the proposed study are also aligned with key questions of the Subduction Cycles and Deformation initiative within the new GeoPRISMS program. Understanding the mechanics and in situ conditions of faulting deformation at subduction plate boundaries has both scientific and social significance in terms of earthquake prediction and disaster prevention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported postdoctoral scholar Hiroko Kitajima, to conduct labroatory measurements of rock and fault zone properties in the Nankai Trough subduction plate boundary. This plate boundary megathrust, offshore SW Honshu, generates repeated great (M > 8) earthquakes and associated tsunamis, the most recent in 1944 and 1946. Dr. Kitajima's research focused on measurement of rock strength, fluid flow, and physical properties, and on linking these data to previous larger-scale regional studies of the subsurface. Through careful laboratory measurements, Kitajima demonstrated a detailed relationship between stress state, compaction behavior, and acoustic wavespeeds in the rock and sediment that comprise the plate boundary system.

One key finding of her work is that regions of previously recognized slow acoustic wavespeed, as mapped by regional surveys, most likely represent regions where pressurized fluids weaken the rock mass and support a large proportion of the weight of overlying rock. Notably, the regions of high fluid pressure and low stress are strongly correlated with anomalous slow earthquakes that likely occur near the edge of the major rupture patches for great earthquakes. Her work - for the first time - demonstrates a clear connection between zones of low stress, high pressure fluids, and slow earthquakes. Her laboratory results also provide key information about rock properties (strength and permeability), and their expected variation with increasing depth and pressure, which will be used in future generations of models of subduction and earthquake processes.
